title: 111_hr1771
content: The Act is titled the "Chesapeake Bay Science, Education, and Ecosystem Enhancement Act of 2009". It includes the reauthorization of the NOAA Chesapeake Bay Office. Section 307 of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992 is amended to specify the qualifications and responsibilities of the Director of the Office, focusing on knowledge and experience in Chesapeake Bay research and resource management. The purpose of amending Section 307 of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992 is to focus on coordinating programs and activities within the organization related to coastal resource stewardship, specifically in the Chesapeake Bay region. The amendment to Section 307 of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992 includes adding provisions for coastal hazards, climate change, and integrated ecosystem assessments. Additionally, the amendment changes the responsible entity from the Environmental Protection Agency to the Chesapeake Executive Council. The amendment to Section 307 of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Authorization Act of 1992 includes changes to support the programs of the Chesapeake Executive Council, removing paragraphs (5) and (7), and adding new functions to be performed. The Director shall establish mechanisms to ensure peer review and scientific merit for projects funded under this section to benefit the Chesapeake Bay area, consulting with the Chesapeake Executive Council. The Director, authorized under this section, collaborates with various entities to support an integrated observations system for the Chesapeake Bay in line with the Chesapeake Bay Agreement. The Director is required to coordinate monitoring activities, identify new data collection needs, collect and analyze scientific information for managing marine resources and habitats in the Chesapeake Bay. The Director may support the development of the Chesapeake Bay Interpretive Buoy System, including establishing the Captain John Smith Chesapeake National Historic Trail and providing real-time data for trail users. The Administrator may establish a Chesapeake Bay watershed education and training program to inspire stewardship of Chesapeake Bay and incorporate the Interpretive Buoy System into the regional network of observatories. The Office offers Bay watershed education programs to improve understanding of the Chesapeake Bay ecosystem, provide community education for watershed protection, and meet the educational goals of the Chesapeake 2000 Agreement through a grant program. The Office offers education and training projects to enhance understanding of environmental issues in the Chesapeake Bay watershed, including classroom education, watershed experiences, and teacher professional development. The Office provides education and training projects for teachers in the Chesapeake Bay watershed, focusing on disseminating education materials, demonstrating field methods, building organizational capacity for environmental education programs, and educating local land use officials. The Director collaborates with relevant Federal agencies to educate local land use officials on the relationship between land use and natural resource protection. Additionally, a Chesapeake Bay coastal living resources management and habitat program may be established to support the management and restoration of priority habitats and living resources in the area. The Director may carry out grants, contracts, and agreements to support oyster restoration, aquaculture, submerged vegetation programs, and coastal habitat protection under the Chesapeake Bay coastal living resources management and habitat program. The Director may carry out grants, contracts, and agreements to support oyster restoration, aquaculture, submerged vegetation programs, and coastal habitat protection under the Chesapeake Bay coastal living resources management and habitat program. Activities include habitat mapping, assessment techniques, scientific research transfer, information sharing, and other relevant actions determined by the Director. The Administrator submits biennial reports to Congress and the Secretary of Commerce on the activities and progress of the Chesapeake Bay protection program. The reports include an action plan for the next 2 years, recommending research, monitoring, and data collection activities to implement the strategy. Integration of National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration activities is also recommended. The Administrator may enter into contracts, leases, grants, or agreements to carry out the purposes of the Act related to the protection and restoration of Chesapeake Bay. The Director can utilize resources of other departments or agencies for these purposes. The Director may accept donations for the protection and restoration of the Chesapeake Bay from various entities, including the United States and state governments. Definitions include the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the Chesapeake Bay Agreement for restoration goals. The Chesapeake Bay Agreement aims to restore and protect the ecosystem and living resources of the Chesapeake Bay. The Chesapeake Executive Council, comprised of representatives from various entities, oversees the agreement. The Director of the Chesapeake Bay Office is responsible for implementing the agreement. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the agreement. Authorization of appropriations for the Chesapeake Bay Agreement includes $17,000,000 for fiscal year 2011, $18,700,000 for fiscal year 2012, $20,570,000 for fiscal year 2013, and $22,627,000 for fiscal year 2014. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 30, 2009. Attest: LORRAINE C. MILLER, Clerk.
